etymologies: early 19th century. Apparently related to hip, although the nature of the relationship is unclear

definitions: Especially in Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling: a manoeuvre in which a wrestler lifts an adversary with both arms, often placing a knee between the thighs to throw the opponent off balance, and then swings him or her to the ground.

notes.text: Frequently with modifying word or phrase, as "left leg hipe", "right leg hipe", "inside hipe", "outside hipe", "swinging hipe", etc.

etymologies: early 20th century; earliest use found in Leader (Melbourne). Origin uncertain; said to be from a sound (perhaps an arbitrary one) substituted for arms in shouted commands such as slope arms!, reinterpreted as denoting the firearm itself

definitions: A gun, especially a rifle. Often in "to slope hipe": to bring a weapon into a sloping position.

etymologies: mid 17th century. Origin uncertain. Perhaps the reflex of a borrowing from early Scandinavian

definitions: Of cattle: to butt, push with the head or horns; to gore.

etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Bell's Life in London and Sporting Chronicle. From hipe

definitions: Especially in Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling: to lift and swing (an adversary) to the ground, often placing a knee between the legs to throw him or her off balance.
